Your manager asks you to delegate more work to other engineers so you can scale yourself. What do you do?

Here's the simplest way to remember: think about each piece of work you delegate like a one-pager.

One-pagers include:
‚Ä¢ Problem
‚Ä¢ Goal
‚Ä¢ Solution
‚Ä¢ Alternatives
‚Ä¢ Risks

Start at the top. Always tell them the problem (or the "why"). Then, continue down the list as far as you'd like, but stop when you're confident the other person can handle the rest.

You can use engineering levels/titles as a rule of thumb, but it doesn't always need to map to that. For example,
‚Ä¢ Staff engineer -> stop at "Problem"
‚Ä¢ Senior engineer -> stop at "Goal"
‚Ä¢ Mid-level engineer -> stop at "Solution"
‚Ä¢ Entry/Junior engineer -> cover most or all

When you want to challenge them, stop earlier. Let them take on more and give them that growth opportunity.

This framework covers what level of detail to provide, but of course, there's more to delegation than that. To get all the details, join 95k+ engineers and check my latest article: https://lnkd.in/ea-JjkKA

After landing a $350k offer in big tech, my friend quoted this interview tip as what helped him the most in landing the job.

Don't answer the question. Answer the question BEHIND the question.

Here's an example:

‚Ä¢ Interviewer asks... "Tell me about your biggest failure"
‚Ä¢ You respond by telling them about a big project that didn't ship on time and everyone moved on. That feels like a failure, right?

The problem is, the question behind the question was, "How well do you learn from your big failures?" So you can still tell the story about your biggest failure, but you need to touch on what you learned from it! Every answer you give uncovers more to the interviewer about how you are to work with (the pie below).

Here are some more examples:
‚Ä¢ Biggest disagreement -> Can you work with others? (not a chance to brag about swapping teams due to arguments)
‚Ä¢ A project you are proud of -> How large is your scope and do you approach projects methodically?
‚Ä¢ A time when you missed a deadline -> Do you let others know ahead of time when your estimate is off? How do you approach your relationship with stakeholders?

Each question has something underlying the interviewer is trying to get at.

Figure out what it is. Answer THAT question and you'll see the offers start coming in.

--
The thing is, this framework isn't just useful for interviews. You can use it when you're fielding questions during a presentation, or when you're dealing with hard questions from your manager on why something hasn't shipped.

To see how AND learn 4 other top communication frameworks like this one, click the link next to my profile picture.

3 unspoken git tricks that save you TONS of time (no one else shares these):

1. git checkout -

What does it do? It switches you to your previous branch. Instead of typing it all out, you can just say "-".

"git checkout jcutler-my-favorite-branch" becomes "git checkout -". I even have an alias set up for git checkout so it becomes "gco -"

AND you can extend this with "git merge -" to merge the last branch you were on, or "cd -" to switch to your previous directory.

2. git bisect

It's the most underrated debugging tool. When something that WAS working starts breaking, run "git bisect start." It will use binary search to figure out the exact commit that broke it in lg(n) tries. 

Because it uses binary search, it can find the bad commit across 1000+ commits in just 10 tries.

3. git checkout HEAD@{1.week.ago}

Or more generally, git checkout branchname@{timeframe}. You can use this to supercharge your git bisect skills. When you use "git bisect", you need to start by finding a "good" and "bad" commit. 

You can easily find the good commit by trying different times of the codebase with this trick.

Any other git tricks like this that don't get enough love?

This one communication shift took my friend from rejections to landing a senior 270k offer in big tech.

‚ùå Before, he'd get a question like, "Tell me about how you made an impact on your team."

And he'd answer like, "Yeah, there was this one time... < speak for a minute on the story >... oh and there was this other time too... < another one >." 

But the interviewer would already be lost by the end of the first one. They want someone senior, someone who can take a step back first.

I told him, you need to show your STRUCTURED thought process. Seniors speak in bullet points first, then details after.

‚úÖ So he switched it to, "Sure. When I'm making impact on the team, I like to think about 3 things--opportunity, effort, and risk. Each quarter, we map projects on these axes and one of the projects I proposed had high opportunity and medium effort/risk. Let me tell you more about that one, why I worked on it, and how I drove it forward..."

Once he switched to this, his interviewer's eyes started lighting up early on in his answer. He finally figured it out. Then, the offers followed.

So why is the second one better?
1. It shows you don't just jump into solutions.
2. It shows your decision criteria for action. You won't work on unimpactful work.
3. It gives your interviewer an overview first, almost like an "agenda" at the start of a presentation. They know what to expect.

Before you answer, take a step back, share your thought process, and show your structured thinking. Don't just dive in and start going off on stories.

This framework I never knew I needed got me compliments on my communication within a week.

It's called MECE.

Huh? mice? No. MECE üòÇ. It stands for "Mutually Exclusive, Collectively Exhaustive." It forces your communication to be structured.

Let's take an incident investigation as an example. Many times, engineers are dropping messages in the channel like throwing darts.

‚ùå Before: "It could be the landing page. No, that's not it. Maybe seasonality? Nope, that's not it either... anyone have other ideas?"

‚úÖ After: "If signups are down, it's either actually down or it's a false positive. If it's a false positive, we can check for seasonality or a data issue. If it's an actual drop, it could be that it's iOS only, android only, or both. Let's narrow it down."

MECE tells you to come up with all the mutually exclusive and many options as possible upfront, then narrow down and cross out. 

This has a few benefits:
1. You can literally SEE the structure via a tree this gives your communication and thinking
2. Once you see it, you can delegate each of those to others working on the issue
3. Finally, you can cross out each item on the tree as you go, and give accurate estimates to leaders of when it'll be resolved. No more, "we're not sure when it'll be fixed. It's too ambiguous." 

To apply it yourself, before your next message, think about how you can communicate using a "tree structure" like the one on the right. Avoid windy roads and darts.

Have you heard of MECE before and where else do you think you can use it?

Here's a simple trick to avoid your proposals getting rejected: Don't make it a "yes" or "no" decision. 

Make it a "which one" decision. And make your recommendation the obvious choice.

When you say "Can I do <x>?" it's a "yes" or "no" decision. Most of the time, especially when your request might be to another team, the easiest thing is for them to say no. That keeps the status quo which feels safe.

When you provide options, it makes the best choice for the business clear and easy to pick.

Here's a before and after example.

‚ùå Before: Can you add rate limiting to the search endpoint? Our frontend is sending too many requests.

‚úÖ After:
Hi team, we're seeing high request volumes on the search endpoint. We have a few options to address this:
1. Backend rate limiting (recommended). All clients will be supported out of the box.
2. Add client side throttling. However, all clients will need to be updated
3. If we do nothing, we'll keep hitting our max load and failing requests

What are your thoughts?

This is a simplified example, but the "after" did a few things:
‚Ä¢ It reduces cognitive load by calling out ways we can solve it up front
‚Ä¢ It makes it really weird to choose option 3. It's clear that (1) or (2) will be better than doing nothing. 
‚Ä¢ It makes it really easy to pick option 1. It's already been laid out as recommended and shows why it's the best choice.

Combined, it leads to you getting the outcome you want.

--

I know an engineer who has been stuck in a mid-level role for 30+ years because he doesn‚Äôt care what his managers think. He cares about technical excellence. That is great, but it won‚Äôt get you promoted. 

Technical excellence alone does not get engineers promoted because technical excellence alone does not create business value.  To get promoted, especially at higher levels, an engineer needs to make it clear that they have an impact in at least one of these three things: 

1) Revenue Generation

This could mean they launch new features/products, facilitate payments, build systems to handle more customers, or a number of other things. However, the connection between the engineer‚Äôs work and the revenue or opportunity for revenue should be clear. 

2) Cost Reduction

On the other side of revenue is cost reduction. A business‚Äôs profits increase when its costs decrease, so doing any work that improves the efficiency of the business will be seen as valuable. 

3) Moat Construction

If an engineer‚Äôs work doesn‚Äôt have direct impact on profit but does help create a competitive advantage for the company, this will also be seen as incredibly valuable. 

The ways in which an engineer can influence each of these three things is practically unlimited, but the important thing for engineers to understand is that doing value-adding work will lead to promotion. Doing maintenance work (exclusively) leads to a maintenance position. 

This may be a very stable job, which is great if that is what you want. But it won‚Äôt be a fast-growing or far-reaching career. If you want one of those, you have to create growth for the company. 

I wrote an article for Jordan Cutler‚Äôs ‚ÄúHigh Growth Engineer‚Äù newsletter that goes through how you can become an engineer that drives impact and gets promoted to higher and higher roles. 

The insights come from my 25+ years as an engineering leader throughout my career, based directly on what has led me to promote scores of engineers.

üö´ Stop building agents. Here's what you should build instead.

Using agents in production code relinquishes all control to the LLM. While LLMs are smart, they're not THAT smart and will get many things wrong, like...
‚Ä¢ What tools should be used
‚Ä¢ When work should get handed off to the next agent
‚Ä¢ What the output should look like

Agents are also highly non-deterministic. So the results of a documentation generation agent can make all your docs look inconsistent.

‚úÖ Here are the five AI patterns you should know that aren't agents.
1. Prompt chaining: Call an LLM with a function. Get structured data. Feed that into the next LLM
2. Parallelization: Break up LLM calls across multiple, parallelizable functions. It speeds up the final result and results in higher quality since the LLM can just focus on one thing for each prompt
3. Routing: LLM classifies the input to a predefined set of values, then you call regular code based on what it returned
4. Orchestrator & worker: LLM takes input and generates a dynamic set of substeps from the options available. Those substeps are passed off to workers for processing
5. Evaluation & optimization: LLM takes a result and acts as an evaluator. If it doesn't meet the criteria provided, it loops back and iterates on it, like a newspaper editor.

These patterns and code snippets are all documented in the latest High Growth Engineer article if you'd like to learn more: https://lnkd.in/eRXw6dar. Shout-out to Hugo Bowne-Anderson , the guest author for this article.

And credit to Anthropic and their original article that came up with these patterns üôè

It's the first impression that a hiring manager gets of you, and you must leave a good one.

4. Find the hiring manager or recruiter responsible for the role on LinkedIn
I would contact that person through LinkedIn and ask them a few questions about the role. Something that would be interesting for me to know and that would give me a better overview of what I can expect.

I would record a video, it would be a Loom video or something else, where I would share improvements (suggestions) to the product or service related to the company I am applying to. I would submit my CV and send the hiring manager the video.
